docs.text: Sudhakar's Notebook Welcome to my Personal Blog . The blog is structured based on my favorite Tim Ferriss quote "Borrow liberally, combine uniquely, and create your own." Borrow Liberally : Nothing can come from vacuum. My favorite medium to gain knowledge is reading. I like to take notes and summarize into essays to clarify my thinking and understanding. You can find it below as Worldly Wisdom Combine Uniquely : Most of the thinking happens when we isolate the first principles and try to fit them into the larger picture. This is maintained in a single document below Mind Garden Create Your Own : This is my own works, based on the previous two steps. They are part of Essays Worldly Wisdom These are summaries and notes I've taken while reading. I'm following zettelkasten system to learn and store knowledge. Notes are taken while reading and Summaries are written in my own words. So Good They Can't Ignore You Deep Work Mind Garden All my Work in Progress and Unfinished Ideas kept in single document. Essays Lot of exiting things are on the way. You can subscribe to get notified when I publish next big thing. Click to Subscribe If this blog looks odd, It's because I'm taking a hands-on approach. I'm writing entire blog in Markdown with the help of Material for MkDocs and hosting at GitHub .

docs.text: Deep Work by Cal Newport Summary This is my summary for the second Cal Newport's book after So Good They Can't Ignore you . Ironically this is the first book I've read of the two. Some times it is better to read wider before going deep. I got lucky reading this book after The Almanack of Naval Rabikant. Since I've already started my exploration about economically valuable skills, it was great that this book starts from the same point. The rare and valuable skills we need to thrive in the connected world are not only standard areas like communication, economics, business skills, etc. The ability to learn the new skills quickly and be able to produce high quality output in the same is the new currency. As Naval said, people have to learn new technologies in months and can have few years to work, untill the new technology replaces the old one. Even though the time is only few years your knowledge and skill is in trend, we can get rich quickly if we match our skills with the trend and get upto professional quality soon. Notes Rare and Economically Valuable skills: Ability to Learn Quickly Ability to produce outputs at elite level. Kind of people who are going to thrive in digital economy: High skilled workers Superstars in their fields Owners and Investors To gain economically valuable skills, we have to do deep work. Deep work is rare, meaningful and valuable. 4 Philosophies of deep work. Attention Residue, End of the work ritual, Working Memory, GTD Capture Habit. Deep Work Rules Work Deeply (Flow State) Embrace Boredom Make Schedule for Pleasure instead for Deep Work. (Deliberate Practice) Quit Social Media Drain the Shallows.

docs.text: How To Fail at Almost Everything And Still Win Big by Scott Adams Notes Goals are for Losers. Your mind isn't magic. It's a moist computer you can program. The most important metric you can track is your personal energy. Every Skill you acquire doubles your odds of success. Happiness = Health & Freedom. Luck can be managed, sort of. Conquer shyness by being a huge phony (in a good way). Fitness is the lever that moves the world. Simplicity transforms ordinary into amazing. Failure always brings something valuable with it. Don't let it leave until you extract that value from it. If you want the success, figure out the price and then pay it. Small success can grow into big one, but Failure rarely grows into success. Economically Valuable Skills as per Scott Adams: Public Speaking Psychology Business Writing Accounting Design Conversation Overcoming Shyness Second Language Golf Proper Grammar Persuasion Technology Proper Voice Technique

docs.text: Mind Garden 29/April/2022 Getting ready after almost 4 months. Yesterday I met the second person whoi want to know about the status of the blog. Things were busy for the past 1 month with house shifting. Will resume my good work from this week. Lot of exciting things are on the way. First set of books I'm reading are for self improvement. All the good things started when I wanted to explore what is the value I can provide for society. Day by day I'm getting somewhat clear idea about economically valuable skills and how to gain them. So the books I'm starting with are Cal Newport's So Good They Can't Ignore You , Deep Work , Seth Godin's Startup School , Scott Adams' How to fail at everything and Still win Big and Peter Thiel's Zero to One . One thing about Zero To One is I can understand the book is holding some secret from me that I'm not able to comprehend now. Will take another shot at summarizing the book. As Scott Adams would say "Don't let go the failure simply, extract some value out of it". I strongly believe good things will come to those who are ready to receive. I am getting ready, one word at a time. So Good They Can't Ignore You Author starts with the controversial idea called "Don't follow your passion". I liked his examples. We like passionate people who are winning medals and awards. I strongly disagree with the author's understanding with Steve Jobs "Follow your passion" speech. Steve clearly mentions we can Connect the dots only looking backwards . Cal Newport also arriving at the same conclusion where we get better at doing things when we have enough confidence and skills to perform our tasks. He calls the idea as "Career Capital". I started this book to figure out the skills worth learning. This entire blog is motivated to find about what are the economically valuable skills an individual can have. So this book fits perfectly into my exploration. Lets look into Career Capital , the author calls it as Set of Rare and Valuable Skills . How can one go about acquiring those skills. As said before, we can Connect the dots only looking backwards . For example, I'm more interested in story telling. Initially I've burnt my hand with painting. After that most of my life revolves around reading the books and watching complex videos and speak to people about them in a simplified manner. I was happy with feeling superior to them and they are happy with not wasting times with those boring stuff. The story doesn't continue such way once I've joined the college. In campus, it was like I was the dumbest person. So I sticked to discussing movie stories and funny one liners. At that time I didn't know that I'm losing the thing that completes me. When I started working, here the things went back to normal. Here also people preferred simplified stories for complex socio-political issues. I sticked to the topic people want to know about, mostly the day's headline new incident. Now that I look back and reflect, I can easily say the thing I'm passionate about is telling stories. Not the boring Boy meets a Girl type stories. The ones that are happening at the real time. The digestable version of what makes people wake up in the morning. For most of the cases people wake up and show up to office because they have expenses to bear with at the end of the month. But what makes people like Bill Gates to take up all the negative comments and still want to do some change in society. Even today Warren Buffett goes to his office daily and do his job at 90. Of course it is for money but is there anything more to it?
